<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 419, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 84, 744, 291]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 311, 920, 346]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) satisfy the equation \(a^{y} = kx\), where \(a\) and \(k\) are constants. The graph of \(y\) against \(\ln x\) is a straight line passing through the points (1.03, 6.36) and (2.58, 9.00), as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 358, 722, 377]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(k\), giving each value correct to 2 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 359, 920, 377]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 640, 92]]<|/det|>
The curve with equation \(y = x\mathrm{e}^{2x} + 5\mathrm{e}^{-x}\) has a minimum point \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 784, 125]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(M\) satisfies the equation \(x = \frac{1}{3}\ln 5 - \frac{1}{3}\ln (1 + 2x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 74, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula, based on the equation in part (a), to find the \(x\)-coordinate of \(M\) correct to 3 significant figures. Use an initial value of 0.35 and give the result of each iteration to 5 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 83, 623, 314]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 332, 564, 352]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with parametric equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 358, 623, 389]]<|/det|>
\[x = \ln (2t + 3),\qquad y = \frac{2t - 3}{2t + 3}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 396, 690, 416]]<|/det|>
The curve crosses the \(y\)-axis at the point \(A\) and the \(x\)-axis at the point \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 433, 146, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 428, 346, 459]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = \frac{6}{2t + 3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 435, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 437, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 186, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 510, 437, 528]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 682, 92]]<|/det|>
When \(a\) and \(b\) have these values, factorise \(\mathrm{f}(x) - \mathrm{g}(x)\) completely.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 186, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 510, 700, 529]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{cos}\mathrm{e}\mathrm{c}\theta) - \mathrm{g}(\mathrm{cos}\mathrm{e}\mathrm{c}\theta) = 0\) for \(0< \theta < 2\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 705, 92]]<|/det|>
By first expanding \(\cos (2\theta +\theta)\), show that \(\cos 3\theta \equiv 4\cos^3\theta -3\cos \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 551, 186, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 551, 547, 570]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(2\cos^{3}\left(\frac{5}{18}\pi\right) - \frac{3}{2}\cos \left(\frac{5}{18}\pi\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 549, 920, 568]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
